comments:
Im working with Jira v3.5.x and a 403 forbidden error throws me. When tries to validate the task repository connection.

Please see the troubleshooting page to ensure JIRA SOAP/RPC is running: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_FAQ#JIRA_Connector_troubleshooting

Brock: have you seen this one before?

no, but it looks like they have authentication setup on their servlet container.  This means that you have to do two levels of authentication, one with the servlet container (using normal HTTP security) and once again with the Jira application.

Do you know if the server is using NTLM authentication?  There is a plugin for Jira that allows you to skip the login process if the client machines are running windows.  The only way to support this at the moment is to re-wrtie everything to use the JDK HTTP implementation that supports NTLM authentication.  We are mostly using Commons HTTP Client at the moment which doesn't support it correctly.
Really i don't know how can i do to check this ??

Well, when you access the Jira web gui, does the browser prompt you for a username and passsword (not the normal jira login form).  Can you also try with Firefox (since it doesn't support NTLM by default)?  In Firefox type in about:config in the address bar and look for the network.automatic-ntlm-auth.trusted-uris option and make sure it is blank.
The browser show me only the jira login form. I suppouse the server is not using a NTLM authentication, any ideas ?

Ariel: I assume that you have ensured that your credentials are correct before you click "Validate Settings".  Could you try putting in a bogus username/password and see if you get the same stack trace?

Brock: sounds like it's not NTLM, so I'm at a loss as to why the server would return a 403.  Have you seen anything else cause this?

There is definitely some sort of security enabled on the server.  Ariel, are you able to ask your Jira administrator if they have modified the Jira security in any way including adding a second level of authentication.  one thing you could try is to use telnet to connect to the Jira to get a more low level trace:

telnet hostname port
GET /rpc/soap/jirasoapservice-v2 HTTP/1.0

(you need one blank line after the GET).  You will also have to change the URI if jira is not under the root context path.

If that works, you might want to try one of the web URLs like /secure/IssueNavigator.jspa?view=rss&decorator=none&reset=true

other than that, i am out of ideas.

In past days ago im talk with de jira administrators and they disable the RPC/SOAP connection. Currently we enable them and jira connector works fine.

thks a lot :P

Thats for the info.  Jira 3.5 should return a 503 if the interface is disabled, not a 403.  See http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-7067

I will have to test this out.
Thanks for the diagnosis Brock!  I added some of the key points to: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_FAQ#JIRA_Connector_troubleshooting
